#### French-speaking constituencies

The French-speaking constituencies in Belgium play a significant role in shaping the political landscape, particularly during the upcoming 2024 federal elections set for June 9. These constituencies primarily encompass the Wallonia region and the French-speaking voters in Brussels, who collectively elect representatives in the federal government.

In Wallonia, the key political players include the Francophone Socialist Party (PS), the liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR), and the centrist Les Engagés. Recent polls indicate a competitive race, with the MR emerging as a strong contender alongside PS and other left-wing parties like the Workers' Party of Belgium (PTB) gaining traction among the electorate <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/looking-ahead-the-road-to-reinvention-for-belgiums-struggling-political-parties</citation>. The dynamics in these areas illustrate a broader trend towards consolidation for liberal parties, which have traditionally held significant influence within the Francophone community <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1061134/mr-extends-its-lead-among-french-speaking-parties-in-final-election-dash</citation>.

In the Brussels-Capital Region, which serves as the administrative center of Belgium, the voting is divided into multiple electoral constituencies. French-speaking voters have the option to choose representatives from the French-speaking lists, which have tailored their campaigns to resonate with the diverse population of the city. The outcome of these elections will not only influence the structure of local government but also affect the overall composition of the federal parliament, as Brussels is a critical battleground for both Francophone and Dutch-speaking parties <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation>.

The rise of parties advocating for regional reform, coupled with reduced voter turnout expectations, highlights an evolving political landscape for French-speaking constituencies. As the Francophone community navigates issues ranging from social equity to economic policy, the 2024 elections are seen as a pivotal moment for re-evaluating their political strategies and alliances <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.

In summary, the French-speaking constituencies in Belgium are central to the discourse surrounding the 2024 federal elections. The interplay between traditional parties and emerging political movements will significantly impact the direction of federal policies and governance in the nation.
</answer>

As Belgium approaches its federal elections on June 9, 2024, a range of opinion polls have been conducted to gauge public sentiment and voting intentions across the country. These polls reflect the changing political landscape and the dynamics among various parties since the last federal election in May 2019.

The most recent poll conducted by Ipsos shows notable support for the major parties, with the Liberal Reformist Party (MR) leading at 27.4%, followed closely by the Socialist Party (PS) at 24.6%. Other parties, including the Green parties (Ecolo) at 8.1% and the left-wing Workers' Party of Belgium (PVDA/PTB) at 12.9%, are also represented in the polls <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/institute/ipsos</citation>.

The ensuing months will be critical as parties ramp up their campaigns and attempt to sway undecided voters in a landscape marked by fragmentation and multiple parties vying for influence.

As Belgium approaches its federal elections on June 9, 2024, a range of opinion polls have been conducted to gauge public sentiment and voting intentions across the country. ## Background

The 2024 Belgian federal elections are set to take place on June 9, 2024, coinciding with regional and European Parliament elections. This election holds significant importance as it represents a crucial moment in Belgium's intricate political landscape, shaped by a complex system of governance that includes both federal and regional authorities <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/22/world/europe/belgium-2024-election.html</citation>.

These parties' prominence reflects broader trends across Europe, where populist sentiments have gained significant traction in recent years.

The Federal Parliament of Belgium consists of a bicameral system, including the Chamber of Representatives and the Senate. Political dynamics are led by coalition-based governance, where no single party has achieved a clear majority since World War I. As Belgium moves towards the 2024 elections, numerous coalitions are being envisioned, including the potential resurgence of a center-right coalition comprising the N-VA, the liberals (Open VLD and MR), and elements of the Christian Democrats <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/looking-ahead-the-road-to-reinvention-for-belgiums-struggling-political-parties</citation>.

### Senate

The Belgian Senate, part of the country's bicameral parliament, plays a unique role in the political landscape. In the upcoming 2024 Belgian federal elections, the Senate will undergo specific changes in its composition and functioning. Currently, the Senate consists of 60 members, of which 50 senators are appointed by the parliaments of the communities and regions, while 10 are co-opted based on the parties' electoral performance in federal elections <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/22/</citation>.

It is important to note that there will be no direct elections for the Senate during the 2024 federal elections scheduled for June 9. The Senate's makeup remains stable, according to the current law, which means that its members will not be renewed during this election cycle. This reflects an ongoing trend since 2014, when the process for filling Senate seats transitioned to one primarily based on appointments rather than direct elections <citation>https://www.senaat.be/event/20240422-elections2024/20240524-elections2024_nl.html</citation>.

The composition of the Senate can influence the formation of coalitions at the federal level, as it represents additional political interests and regional perspectives. 前面已写的内容：#### French-speaking constituencies

The French-speaking constituencies in Belgium play a significant role in shaping the political landscape, particularly during the upcoming 2024 federal elections set for June 9. These constituencies primarily encompass the Wallonia region and the French-speaking voters in Brussels, who collectively elect representatives in the federal government.

In Wallonia, the key political players include the Francophone Socialist Party (PS), the liberal Mouvement Réformateur (MR), and the centrist Les Engagés. Recent polls indicate a competitive race, with the MR emerging as a strong contender alongside PS and other left-wing parties like the Workers' Party of Belgium (PTB) gaining traction among the electorate <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/looking-ahead-the-road-to-reinvention-for-belgiums-struggling-political-parties</citation>. The dynamics in these areas illustrate a broader trend towards consolidation for liberal parties, which have traditionally held significant influence within the Francophone community <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1061134/mr-extends-its-lead-among-french-speaking-parties-in-final-election-dash</citation>.

In the Brussels-Capital Region, which serves as the administrative center of Belgium, the voting is divided into multiple electoral constituencies. French-speaking voters have the option to choose representatives from the French-speaking lists, which have tailored their campaigns to resonate with the diverse population of the city. The outcome of these elections will not only influence the structure of local government but also affect the overall composition of the federal parliament, as Brussels is a critical battleground for both Francophone and Dutch-speaking parties <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1086432/belgian-elections-2024-who-did-brussels-vote-for</citation>.

The rise of parties advocating for regional reform, coupled with reduced voter turnout expectations, highlights an evolving political landscape for French-speaking constituencies. As the Francophone community navigates issues ranging from social equity to economic policy, the 2024 elections are seen as a pivotal moment for re-evaluating their political strategies and alliances <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.

In summary, the French-speaking constituencies in Belgium are central to the discourse surrounding the 2024 federal elections. The interplay between traditional parties and emerging political movements will significantly impact the direction of federal policies and governance in the nation.
## Opinion Polls

As Belgium approaches its federal elections on June 9, 2024, a range of opinion polls have been conducted to gauge public sentiment and voting intentions across the country. These polls reflect the changing political landscape and the dynamics among various parties since the last federal election in May 2019.

The most recent poll conducted by Ipsos shows notable support for the major parties, with the Liberal Reformist Party (MR) leading at 27.4%, followed closely by the Socialist Party (PS) at 24.6%. Other parties, including the Green parties (Ecolo) at 8.1% and the left-wing Workers' Party of Belgium (PVDA/PTB) at 12.9%, are also represented in the polls <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/institute/ipsos</citation>.

In addition to the Ipsos poll, a comprehensive survey conducted from May 28 to May 31, 2024, indicates that the New Flemish Alliance (N-VA) and the radical right-wing party Vlaams Belang (VB) remain significant contenders in the Flemish region, although exact percentages were not disclosed <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1079133/belgium-braces-for-sundays-electoral-showdown-with-final-opinion-polls</citation>. The context is critical, as the country has experienced increasing political polarization and shifting alliances in the run-up to this election. 

As political uncertainty looms, the latest predictions suggest that the current governing coalition, comprised of diverse political factions, could see a reduction in seats, complicating the formation of future governing coalitions <citation>https://www.fitchsolutions.com/bmi/country-risk/rising-political-polarisation-ahead-belgian-federal-elections-17-04-2024</citation>.

These opinion polls not only provide insight into voter preferences but also highlight the potential consequences of political alliances and the overall stability of the Belgian government heading into 2024. The ensuing months will be critical as parties ramp up their campaigns and attempt to sway undecided voters in a landscape marked by fragmentation and multiple parties vying for influence.
## Background

The 2024 Belgian federal elections are set to take place on June 9, 2024, coinciding with regional and European Parliament elections. This election holds significant importance as it represents a crucial moment in Belgium's intricate political landscape, shaped by a complex system of governance that includes both federal and regional authorities <citation>https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/22/world/europe/belgium-2024-election.html</citation>.

Historically, Belgium has been characterized by a fragmented political system marked by linguistic and regional divisions between the Dutch-speaking Flanders region and the French-speaking Wallonia. The elections are expected to be a pivotal point for various political parties, particularly with the anticipated rise of right-wing and far-right factions, such as the New Flemish Alliance (N-VA) and Vlaams Belang (VB), which have been polling strongly <citation>https://politico.eu/article/belgium-far-right-election-extremist-landslide-elections-in-europe-results-2024/</citation>. These parties' prominence reflects broader trends across Europe, where populist sentiments have gained significant traction in recent years.

The Federal Parliament of Belgium consists of a bicameral system, including the Chamber of Representatives and the Senate. Political dynamics are led by coalition-based governance, where no single party has achieved a clear majority since World War I. As Belgium moves towards the 2024 elections, numerous coalitions are being envisioned, including the potential resurgence of a center-right coalition comprising the N-VA, the liberals (Open VLD and MR), and elements of the Christian Democrats <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/looking-ahead-the-road-to-reinvention-for-belgiums-struggling-political-parties</citation>.

The expectation of low voter turnout, the lowest since 1893, adds another layer of complexity to the elections, suggesting potential voter disengagement amid a tumultuous political climate shaped by economic challenges, social issues, and the lingering effects of the COVID-19 pandemic <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.

As the campaigning intensifies, political leaders and parties will be keenly navigating the landscape to secure necessary coalitions to govern, reflecting the shifting allegiances and priorities of the Belgian electorate. The outcome of these elections could greatly influence Belgium’s domestic and European policy directions in the coming years.
## Preface

The 2024 Belgian federal elections, held on June 9, represented a significant moment in Belgium's political landscape. As the first federal election post-COVID-19 pandemic, these elections not only concerned the immediate political climate but also reflected underlying trends in voter sentiment and party dynamics, marking a pivotal transition in the nation's governance.

Belgium's electoral structure is complex, comprising three separate parliaments—at federal, regional, and European levels—and these elections included contests for all 150 seats in the Chamber of Representatives, alongside regional and EU elections. This layered governance system plays a crucial role in shaping the country's political discourse.

Pre-election polls indicated a concerning trend towards the right, with the far-right Vlaams Belang party emerging as a leading contender, projected to capture a significant portion of the electorate. This shift towards populism and radical ideologies raised alarms about the potential implications for coalition politics and governance in Belgium, a country known for its intricate power-sharing arrangements amidst linguistic divides between the Dutch-speaking Flanders and French-speaking Wallonia.

As Belgium approaches the 2024 federal elections, several incumbent politicians have announced their decision not to seek re-election. ## Electoral System

The electoral system in Belgium is characterized by its use of proportional representation, which is designed to ensure that the distribution of seats in the Chamber of Representatives reflects the overall votes received by political parties. Federal elections, including the 2024 Belgian federal elections, occur every five years and are held concurrently with regional and European elections, allowing voters to cast ballots for multiple layers of governance on the same day, which was scheduled for 9 June 2024 <citation>https://www.electionpassport.com/electoral-systems/belgium/</citation>.

Belgium's electoral structure has undergone significant changes, especially following the sixth state reform in December 2011, which enhanced the autonomy of regional governments. As a result, the federal Senate has transitioned into a regional chamber that represents the various federal entities of Belgium. The Chamber of Representatives consists of 150 members, all elected through a system known as D'Hondt, a method of party-list proportional representation. Under this system, voters in each electoral district cast their votes for a party, and then the seats are allocated based on the overall proportion of votes each party receives <citation>https://electiopedia.com/elections-in-belgium/</citation>.

In Belgium, voting is compulsory, meaning that it is required for eligible citizens to participate in elections, which has implications for voter turnout and political engagement. Approximately 7.7 million citizens are eligible to vote, and the law mandates participation from all individuals aged 18 and over <citation>https://www.reuters.com/article/world/factbox-key-facts-about-belgiums-electoral-system-idUSL10246183/</citation>. The 2024 elections are notable as they also include a provision allowing 16- and 17-year-olds to vote in European elections, reflecting a broader trend toward increasing youth engagement in the democratic process <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/a-guide-to-the-elections-the-voting-process-in-belgium</citation>.

This electoral framework aims to facilitate a diverse political representation, giving smaller parties a chance to gain seats proportional to their support among the electorate. The coalition nature of Belgian politics often leads to fragmented parliaments, necessitating the formation of multi-party coalitions to establish a government <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1008651/belgian-elections-for-dummies</citation>.

In conclusion, the electoral system of Belgium is instrumental in shaping its complex political landscape, promoting a multiparty environment where diverse political opinions can be represented within the federal structure. The proportional representation system not only allows for equitable representation of parties in the Chamber of Representatives but also underscores the importance of voter participation in maintaining democratic integrity within the nation.

## Electoral System

The electoral system in Belgium is characterized by its use of proportional representation, which is designed to ensure that the distribution of seats in the Chamber of Representatives reflects the overall votes received by political parties. Federal elections, including the 2024 Belgian federal elections, occur every five years and are held concurrently with regional and European elections, allowing voters to cast ballots for multiple layers of governance on the same day, which was scheduled for 9 June 2024 <citation>https://www.electionpassport.com/electoral-systems/belgium/</citation>.

Belgium's electoral structure has undergone significant changes, especially following the sixth state reform in December 2011, which enhanced the autonomy of regional governments. As a result, the federal Senate has transitioned into a regional chamber that represents the various federal entities of Belgium. The Chamber of Representatives consists of 150 members, all elected through a system known as D'Hondt, a method of party-list proportional representation. Under this system, voters in each electoral district cast their votes for a party, and then the seats are allocated based on the overall proportion of votes each party receives <citation>https://electiopedia.com/elections-in-belgium/</citation>.

In Belgium, voting is compulsory, meaning that it is required for eligible citizens to participate in elections, which has implications for voter turnout and political engagement. Approximately 7.7 million citizens are eligible to vote, and the law mandates participation from all individuals aged 18 and over <citation>https://www.reuters.com/article/world/factbox-key-facts-about-belgiums-electoral-system-idUSL10246183/</citation>. This electoral framework aims to facilitate a diverse political representation, giving smaller parties a chance to gain seats proportional to their support among the electorate. The coalition nature of Belgian politics often leads to fragmented parliaments, necessitating the formation of multi-party coalitions to establish a government <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1008651/belgian-elections-for-dummies</citation>.

In conclusion, the electoral system of Belgium is instrumental in shaping its complex political landscape, promoting a multiparty environment where diverse political opinions can be represented within the federal structure. The proportional representation system not only allows for equitable representation of parties in the Chamber of Representatives but also underscores the importance of voter participation in maintaining democratic integrity within the nation.

## Aftermath

The aftermath of the 2024 Belgian federal elections, held on June 9, marked a significant turning point in the country's political landscape. The elections resulted in a noteworthy shift towards the right, with the New Flemish Alliance (N-VA) and the Francophone liberal Reformist Movement (MR) emerging as the biggest winners. N-VA secured 25.6% of the Flemish votes, maintaining its status as the largest party in Belgium, while MR followed with 20 seats in the Federal Parliament <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1085399/the-belgian-elections-biggest-winners-and-losers</citation>.

The elections were characterized by one of the lowest voter turnouts since compulsory voting was introduced in 1893, indicative of public dissatisfaction and disengagement from the political process <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2492986</citation>.
